resources.string:
This is the debug menu configured by you

 It should contain useful information, like the version number of the app, the build date, or information about the device it's running on.

 You can use it to display network requests, track analytics events, see custom logs, session-related data or anything that you consider useful for debugging potential issues or simplifying the testing of your app.

 It can also contain various dynamic features, like switches, radio groups, buttons, sliders, etc. that you can use to set up a "God mode" during development.
Here is a switch. It does nothing.
The switch is on. Nothing happened.
The switch is off. Still nothing.

Best of all: none of this will be present in your release builds, as the noop implementation that should be used in those situations has the same public API (so it won't break your code) but none of the underlying logic.

 The module configuration can be changed at any time. For example in the case of this application you will see very different Beagle setups as you explore the various case studies.

 The library was written in Kotlin and supports API levels 16 and above.

Welcome!\n\n Beagle is a free, open-source library that adds a smart and easily customizable debug menu to the internal builds of your Android apps.

The true power of the library lies in modules that require a tiny bit of customization. Check out how Beagle can be useful in the following situations:
Built-in modules that can be added with almost no configuration and are useful for most projects.
Simplify the QA process by presenting a list of test accounts and automatically filling in the necessary login information.
Test different implementations without creating new builds.
Making sure that every required event is tracked from an admin panel can be cumbersome. Why not display the events right in the app, in real time?
See the incoming and outgoing REST API calls and their formatted JSON payload to quickly debug potential issues.
Change the application\'s base URL at runtime.
Filling your development database with random content like \"d23fMIMnow81\" makes your app look bad. Why not add a simple Lorem Ipsum generator instead?
